ALLEN: Well, we've kind of progressed through a couple different phases; the first one was a response phase and we were involved extensively in, as you know, urban search and rescue--the tough task of remains removal; the unwatering of the city and so forth.
That has all been taken care of.

We are shifting now to taking a look at some of the needs of our folks that went to evacuation shelters or were put up in hotels, and trying to come up with better transitional housing solutions for them.

There was an extraordinary displacement of people as a result of this natural disaster, and I think when the numbers finally come in, we're going to find out it's one of the largest displacements of US populations after one of these events in our history, and trying to reconcile where these people need to go and get them into the housing is probably the biggest challenge I've got before me right now.
As you know, FEMA had goal of getting everybody out of emergency shelters by last weekend.
It was not able to realize that goal.
How many people still need shelter?
Vice Adm.
ALLEN: Well, you have to look at the entire population.
We had approximately 1.5 million people that evacuated the New Orleans area.
And we, at one point in early September, we had about 270,000 people in shelters.
That's down to less than 10,000 right now, and those numbers are dwindling off, and we will ultimately take care of all that.

I wasn't held to a fast deadline on the 15th of October; it was a goal; we tried to achieve it, but I think there are certain cases, especially special needs folks where you need to make sure they're taken care of before you move them out of shelters.

But there's a much larger number of people that were put up temporarily in hotels and motel rooms, and that is a bad transient situation for anybody, and we're trying to get them into more permanent solutions right now.
